title: Efficient Price, Inefficient Blocks
text:
Abstract Preview
The Big Picture: We tested whether Bitcoin returns follow predictable weekly patterns (like stocks‚Äô famous ‚ÄúMonday effect‚Äù). Using 10+ years of data, we found no reliable day-of-week patterns for trading. However, we discovered something more interesting: Bitcoin users consistently overpay for transactions during predictable times‚Äîweekends and morning hours‚Äîwasting millions of dollars in unnecessary fees.

This research was conducted using comprehensive Bitcoin blockchain data and statistical analysis methods.

title: Efficient Price, Inefficient Blocks
text:
1. Introduction: What We‚Äôre Looking For
Everyone wants to find patterns in Bitcoin prices. The stock market has its ‚ÄúMonday effect‚Äù (where prices supposedly drop on Mondays), so we wondered: does Bitcoin have something similar?
We tested Bitcoin‚Äôs daily returns across different time windows to see if certain days consistently perform better or worse. We used several statistical tests (think of them as different microscopes looking at the same data) including ANOVA (which compares averages across groups) and OLS regression (which measures relationships between variables).
Spoiler alert: The price patterns aren‚Äôt there. But we found something better‚Äîpredictable inefficiencies in how people use the Bitcoin network that cost real money.

Our Toolkit:

3. The Price Story: No Magic Trading Days

3.1 The Bottom Line ‚Äî Bitcoin Weekday Effects Don‚Äôt Exist (Interactive Dashboard)




Figure ES. Play with this dashboard to see for yourself: weekday patterns in Bitcoin are weak and unstable. Use the timeframe selector to explore different periods.

What this shows: - Weekday effects are tiny and keep changing - Statistical tests mostly say ‚Äúno significant difference‚Äù (high p-values mean no pattern) - The ‚ÄúMonday effect‚Äù comes and goes‚Äînot something you can trade on


3.2 Is Monday Special? Rolling Analysis Shows: Nope




This chart tracks whether Monday returns are different from other days over rolling windows. The gray bands show our confidence‚Äîwhen they include zero (the dashed line), there‚Äôs no real difference.



3.3 The Statistical Evidence (For Those Who Like Numbers)

Regression ResultsGlobal Tests














Figure 1. How much each weekday differs from Monday (in percentage points). The error bars show our uncertainty‚Äînotice how they all overlap with zero.


Figure 2. Different statistical tests all saying the same thing: weekdays don‚Äôt matter for Bitcoin returns.


Translation: You can‚Äôt reliably make money by trading Bitcoin on specific weekdays. Any patterns you see are probably just random noise that won‚Äôt repeat.

4. The Real Discovery: People Waste Money on Transaction Fees
Now here‚Äôs where it gets interesting. While Bitcoin‚Äôs price is efficiently random, the way people use Bitcoin is predictably inefficient.

4.1 The Damage: How Much Money Gets Wasted




Total Bitcoin wasted by users who paid at least 2√ó more than necessary for their transactions. This is real money down the drain.






4.2 Who‚Äôs Overpaying and When?




Different types of users overpay at different times. This 3D view shows when and how much each group wastes.



4.3 The Network Gets Predictably Busy











4.4 When People Overpay: Clear Patterns Emerge




What this means: People consistently overpay for Bitcoin transactions on weekends and during morning hours (UTC). Unlike price patterns, this is real and persistent‚Äîyou can save money by timing your transactions better.



4.5 The Perfect Storm: Weekends + Rush Hours = Maximum Overpayment




The pattern is clear: Weekend mornings are the worst time to send Bitcoin. The combination of time-of-day and day-of-week creates predictable fee spikes.

section: 6. What Could Go Wrong With Our Analysis?
text:
6. What Could Go Wrong With Our Analysis?
Being honest about limitations: - Time zones matter: We use ET for price data and UTC for blockchain data‚Äîthis could shift patterns slightly - The mempool isn‚Äôt perfect: We use it as a proxy for demand, but it‚Äôs not the whole story - Things change: Bitcoin has evolved (Ordinals, Lightning Network, etc.), so patterns might shift - Our thresholds are arbitrary: We say 2√ó overpayment is ‚Äútoo much‚Äù‚Äîbut maybe 1.5√ó or 3√ó would show different patterns

title: Efficient Price, Inefficient Blocks
text:
7. So What? The Practical Takeaways
The contrast is striking: - Bitcoin‚Äôs price: No weekly patterns you can trade on (efficient market) - Bitcoin‚Äôs blockchain: Clear, predictable patterns in fee overpayment (inefficient usage)
What you can actually do: - Don‚Äôt send urgent transactions on weekend mornings - Use dynamic fee estimation tools (not fixed fee settings) - If your transaction can wait, wait for off-peak times - Businesses should implement smart fee policies that adapt to network conditions

title: Efficient Price, Inefficient Blocks
text:
8. What‚Äôs Next: Testing These Ideas
We need to backtest strategies like: - ‚ÄúAlways wait 2 hours if it‚Äôs a weekend morning‚Äù - ‚ÄúNever pay more than 1.5√ó the 10th percentile fee‚Äù - ‚ÄúDelay non-urgent transactions when blocks are >90% full‚Äù - ‚ÄúUsing todays conjestion data to preditct tomoreos chage in price‚Äù
Success metrics would include: - How much in fees you save (in %) - How long your transactions get delayed - Whether the strategy works in different market conditions - Proving correlation to conjestion and volitiolity

D. The Math (For Those Who Care)

Return calculation: r_t = ln(C_t/C_{t‚àí1}) ‚Äî natural log of price ratios
Weekend gap: ln(Monday_close/Friday_close) ‚Äî captures the full weekend movement
Block fullness: (space used / maximum space) √ó 100%
Clearing fee: The 10th percentile fee in each block (what you actually needed to pay)
Overpayment ratio: (what you paid / clearing fee) ‚Äî values >2 mean serious overpayment
Statistical methods: HAC standard errors for prices, HC3 for blockchain analysis

text:
Glossary of Bitcoin Terms
Block: A batch of Bitcoin transactions processed together, like a bus that leaves every ~10 minutes
Blockspace: The limited room in each block for transactions (think: seats on the bus)
Block fullness: How crowded a block is (percentage of maximum capacity used)
Clearing fee/price: The minimum fee that would have gotten your transaction into a block
Fee rate: How much you pay per unit of transaction size (satoshis per virtual byte)
Mempool: The waiting room where transactions sit before being included in a block
Overpayment ratio (OPR): How many times more than necessary someone paid (2√ó means double)
Satoshi (sat): The smallest unit of Bitcoin (0.00000001 BTC)
Transaction fee: What you pay miners to include your transaction in a block
UTC: Coordinated Universal Time (the time zone used for blockchain data)
Virtual byte (vB): A measure of transaction size that determines how much blockspace it uses
Statistical Terms:
ANOVA: Analysis of Variance - a test that compares averages across multiple groups
Dummy variable: A yes/no (1/0) variable used in regression (e.g., ‚ÄúIs it Monday?‚Äù)
Eta-squared (Œ∑¬≤): Measures how much of the variation is explained by our groupings
HAC/Newey-West: Methods to calculate accurate error bars when data is volatile
Kruskal-Wallis: A statistical test that doesn‚Äôt assume normal distributions
OLS regression: Ordinary Least Squares - a method to measure relationships between variables
p-value: The probability that a pattern is just random chance (lower = more significant)
R¬≤: How much of the variation our model explains (0 = nothing, 1 = everything)
